body: Mandela is born to Hendry Mphakanyiswa, a Thembu chief, and Nosekeni Qunu in the Umtata district of the Transkei, at a time when virtually all of Africa was under European colonial rule.
title: Nelson Mandela Born
caption: Nelson Mandela leaves the Intercontinental Hotel after a photoshoot with celebrity photographer Terry O'Neil on June 26, 2008 in London, England.

body: Expelled from University of Fort Hare, a leading institution for blacks, for role in a student strike.
title: Expelled from University of Fort Hare
Joins African National Congress, South Africa's main campaigner for black equality
caption: African National Congress (ANC) President Nelson Mandela greets supporters behind the fence in a mining town of Randfontein west of Johannesburg Nov. 25, 1993. Mandela tours the area as part of his campaign for the April 27, 1994 election.

body: Mandela receives his BA from Fort Hare after completing correspondence courses through University of South Africa.
title: Receives university degree

body: The National Party, dominated by white Dutch-descended Afrikaners, is elected to power and begins installing apartheid, a system of complete racial segregation. It will rule without interruption for 46 years.
title: Apartheid begins

body: Mandela leads the Defiance Campaign, encouraging people to break racial separation laws. Convicted under Suppression of Communism Act, banned from attending gatherings and leaving Johannesburg. Passes exam to qualify as an attorney and, with Tambo, forms the first black law partnership in the country.
title: Leads Defiance Campaign, qualifies as attorney

body: Mandela marries Winnie Nomzamo Madikizela, a social worker, after divorcing Evelyn Mase, his first wife.
title: Marries social worker after divorcing his first wife

body: The wing of the African National Congress is known as Umkhonto we Sizwe, or Spear of the Nation.
title: Helps establish ANC guerrilla wing

body: At a time when many African colonies have become independent and Mandela is on trial for sabotage, he declares from the dock that he is "prepared to die" for a democratic South Africa.
title: Mandela says he is 'prepared to die' for democratic South Africa
caption: Circa 1964: Nelson Mandela, President of the African National Congress (left) in discussion with C Andrews, a Cape Town teacher.

body: Mandela and six others are sentenced to life imprisonment and sent to notorious Robben Island to serve their sentences.
title: Mandela, six others sentenced to life in prison

body: Refuses a government offer of release on condition he agrees to a kind of exile in his native Transkei.
title: Mandela refuses offer of release on condition of exile

body: While in hospital for prostate surgery he is visited by Justice Minister Kobie Coetsee, the beginning of a political and diplomatic process that will lead on Dec. 9, 1988, to his transfer to better prison conditions on the mainland, north of Cape Town.
title: Process to improve Mandela's prison conditions begins

body: Another release offer, on condition he renounce violence. In fiery refusal, read by his daughter Zindzi at a rally, Mandela says burden is on the government to renounce violence, end apartheid and negotiate.
title: Mandela refuses another release offer
caption: A picture taken on Feb. 10, 1995 shows former South African President Nelson Mandela visiting his former cell in notorious Robben Island prison. During his incarceration he worked in a limestone quarry for 13 years on Robben Island off the Cape Town coast, which may have affected his health in later life.

title: Meets President P.W. Botha
Meets Botha's successor, F.W. de Klerk

body: At the opening of Parliament, de Klerk announces the legalization of all political organizations including the African National Congress.
title: All political organizations become legal in South Africa
caption: Anti-apartheid leader and African National Congress (ANC) member Nelson Mandela addresses at a funeral of 12 people died during recent township unrests in Soweto, Sept. 20, 1990, in Soweto.

title: De Klerk announces Mandela will be released the next day
caption: via https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5s8xkjG8bx4

body: Mandela walks out of prison, hand in hand with wife Winnie, to cheering crowds.
title: Mandela released from prison
caption: Anti-apartheid leader and African National Congress (ANC) member Nelson Mandela (C, L) and his wife Winnie raise fists upon Mandela's release from Victor Verster prison on Feb. 11, 1990 in Paarl.

title: Mandela and de Klerk share Nobel Peace Prize
caption: South African National Congress President Nelson Mandela addresses in Tokoza a crowd of residents from the Phola park squatter camp during his tour of townships Sept. 5, 1990.

body: Mandela is inaugurated as South Africa's first black president after the African National Congress wins South Africa's first all-race election.
title: Mandela becomes South Africa's first black president
caption: South African National Congress (ANC) President Nelson Mandela on March 15, 1994 in Mmabatho gives a clenched fist to supporters upon his arrival for his first election rally for April 27 general elections.

title: Mandela granted a divorce from Winnie
Mandela weds former Mozambican first lady Graca Machel on his 80th birthday

body: Mandela retires after one term, a rarity among African presidents, but continues to be active in causes promoting world peace, supporting children and fighting AIDS.
title: Mandela retires after one term
caption: Former South African President Nelson Mandela greets Simbi Mahlanza, left, and Mosa Mahlanza, second from left, as he arrives at a visit with Los Angeles-area youths and youth leaders Saturday, Nov. 18, 2000, at the St. Regis Hotel in the Century City district of Los Angeles. The event was jointly hosted by the South African consulate and the Los Angeles-based Artists for a Free South Africa.

body: In speech, calls U.S. President George W. Bush arrogant and shortsighted for ignoring the U.N. on Iraq.
title: Mandela chastises Bush over Iraq
Mandela announces retirement from public life
caption: Former South African President Nelson Mandela (R) hugs South African Anglican Bishop Desmond Tutu as they pay tribute to their late friend Walter Sisulu, at the apartheid struggle hero's state funeral in Soweto May 17, 2003.

body: Mandela waves to the crowd at Soccer City stadium in Johannesburg as South Africa bids farewell to the 2010 soccer World Cup. Driven in a small golf cart and seated alongside wife, Graca Machel, the smiling, warmly dressed Mandela is welcomed by a thunderous mix of vuvuzelas and roars from the crowd.
title: Mandela makes 2010 World Cup appearance

body: Mandela meets at his home with Michelle Obama, her two daughters and other Obama relatives.
title: Obama family visits Mandela at his home

body: Mandela spends nearly three weeks in a hospital, where he is treated for a lung infection and has a procedure to remove gallstones.
title: Mandela spends 3 weeks in hospital for lung infection, gallstones

body: State television broadcasts footage of a visit by President Jacob Zuma and other ANC leaders to Mandela at his Johannesburg home. Zuma said at the time that Mandela was in good shape, but the footage — the first public images of Mandela in nearly a year — showed him silent and unresponsive, even when Zuma tried to hold his hand.
title: Public images appear to show Mandela in poor health at home
caption: In an image taken from video, South African President Jacob Zuma, left, sits with the ailing anti-apartheid icon Nelson Madela in April.

body: The government says Mandela is admitted to a hospital with a recurring lung infection. Officials describe his condition as serious but stable.
title: Mandela admitted to hospital in 'serious but stable' condition
caption: A person walk past  a display at the Cape Town Honours Nelson Mandela exhibition at the Cape Town Civic Centre as part of the Cape Town Honours Nelson Mandela exhibition on June 27, 2013 in Cape Town, South Africa.

title: Mandela dies at age 95
caption: via http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UqoYmx_L-Xs
